conclusion: Use the ideal gas law and properties of a gas at constant temperature.
Temperature at state A is given as 127°C.
Initial state A: pressure 4 atm, volume 1 L; Final state B: pressure 3 atm, volume 3 L.
Use ideal gas law PV = nRT; since temperature is constant, P_A * V_A = P_B * V_B.
Solve for number of moles n: 4 = 9, incorrect, re-evaluate.
Calculate temperature T using ideal gas law: T = PV/(nR).
Convert temperature at state A to Kelvin: 127°C = 318.15 K.
Calculate temperature at state B: T_B = 3 atm * 3 L / V = 9 L/V * 318.15 K / L/V = 2861.45 K.
Calculate temperature at state B: T_B = 2861.45/(n * 8.314 J/(mol·K)).
Equate temperatures at state A and B: 127 = 2861.45.
Calculate temperature at state B: T_B = 2861.45/(0.045 * 8.314) ≈ 1000 K.
Convert temperature to Celsius: T_B = 1000 K = 1000 * 0.6213 = 621.3°C.
Convert temperature at state B to Kelvin: T_B = 621.3 K.
Temperature at state B is 621.3 K.
Convert temperature at state B to Celsius: T_B = 621.3°C.
